headline: An Arizona Republican just proposed a bill that would allow the state legislature to overturn election results
sentences:
Add it up....)

Keep up the good fight Arizona



To: Dr. Franklin

They should be passing a law Making Vote Fraud a Felony with NO BAIL, Less than 10 Fraudulent Votes a LIFE sentence with No Parole, More than 10 fraudulent votes a DEATH SENTENCE



by 8 posted onby eyeamok (founded in cynicism, wrapped in sarcasm)

To: Dr. Franklin

I disagree with this particular bill though - the legislature can demand recounts and ballot verification but can’t just toss out the results if they don’t like them.

To: Dr. Franklin

CNN’s ever blatant gaslighting is beginning to sound a bit desperate...



by 17 posted onby EasySt (Say not this is the truth, but so it seems to me to be, as I see this thing I think I see.#MAGA)

To: ConservativeMind

Good.

An Arizona Republican just proposed a bill that would allow the state legislature to overturn election results

CNN-The Clinton News Network ^ | January 28, 2022 | Chris Cillizza

Posted on by Dr. Franklin

In the wake of the 2020 election, a number of Republican-controlled state legislatures have made moves to make it harder to vote.

by 2 posted onby ifinnegan (Democrats kill babies and harvest their organs to sell)

To: Dr. Franklin

The states with the complainers are states that mostly signed on to the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, which does a worse thing—it will requires negation of a state that voted a different way.

Since the U.S. Constitution gives state legislatures the right to determine the method of electing federal officials from each state, implicit in that power is determining if the executive branch in the state has followed the state law properly.

GOP state Rep. John Fillmore introduced legislation this week that would, among other things, get rid of almost all absentee and early voting in the state and mandate all votes be HAND-counted within 24 hours of polling sites being closed.

Voter ID, paper ballots cast at the poling place by real live properly identified voters, counted by qualified people and monitored by all interested parties...with criminal consequences for those who even attempt to corrupt the process.

...

That legislation like this is even proposed, however, speaks to how far down the rabbit hole Republicans have gone when it comes to Trump's conspiracy theories about the last election.

To: Dr. Franklin

among other things, get rid of almost all absentee and early voting in the state and mandate all votes be HAND-counted within 24 hours of polling sites being closed.

To: Skywise

I disagree with this particular bill though - the legislature can demand recounts and ballot verification but can’t just toss out the results if they don’t like them.

As CNN's Fredreka Schouten reports:

"Under [Fillmore's] proposal, lawmakers would meet to either 'accept or reject election results' following primary and general elections.
"We should have voting, in my opinion, in person, one day on paper, with no electronic means and hand counting that day," Fillmore said on Wednesday in support of his bill.
Disclaimer: Opinions posted on Free Republic are those of the individual posters and do not necessarily represent the opinion of Free Republic or its management.
If legislators reject the results, any qualified voter 'may file an action in the Superior Court to request that a new election be held,' according to the bill.
Fifteen Republican legislators have signed on to Fillmore's bill, including Rep. Mark Finchem, the Trump-endorsed candidate for Arizona secretary of state.

TOPICS:

Government

News/Current Events

Politics/Elections

KEYWORDS:

audit

az

Another headline of screaming propaganda from The Clinton News Network.

by 5 posted onby RideForever (One of the CoVID naturally immune control group)

To: Dr. Franklin

Oh, you mean like the US constitution intended?
We really do not want stupid criminal politicians deciding whether an election, in which they would surely be involved,is an honest election.

To: Dr. Franklin

The other media prattled it the same way yesterday, deliberately ignoring many needed reforms, and many here fell for it.
But even amid this cavalcade of voter restrictions, a new bill proposed by a GOP legislator in Arizona stands out -- and not in a good way.
by 3 posted onby ConservativeMind (Trump: Befuddling Democrats, Republicans, and the Media for the benefit of the US and all mankind.)
Post-election audits should confirm unique ballot image - security hash files for all ballots cast, and complete ballot transit logs.

And then introducing such a bill makes people think these powers are not already specified, in the Constitution.

by 12 posted onby old curmudgeon (There is no situation so bad that the federal government can not make worse.)
Fillmore said lawmakers should possess authority as 'representatives of the people' to review the vote count."
Dems always use every tool they have, whereas R’s can always snatch complete defeat from the jaws of victory.

To: eyeamok

A RICO act for elections



by 11 posted onby Vaquero (Don't pick a fight with an old guy.
On the other hand, if the state legislatures already have this power, then what's the need for a bill?
It is embarrassing that nothing was done about the sham elections of 2020 for now almost 15 months.
But Fillmore's bill would go even further than putting strictures on when and how you can vote.
It would also empower the state legislature to accept or reject election results in the state.
Pre-election audits should show # ballots printed and available with distinct numbering.
What we need is elections conducted in such a way that they are impossible to corrupt.
Lest you think Fillmore is on a lonely quest to subvert democracy, well, he's not.

To: Dr. Franklin

If cheating is proven, ‘overturn’ doesn’t really apply.

To: Dr. Franklin

You don’t need a bill - it’s in the Constitution.
by 15 posted onby BenLurkin (The above is not a statement of fact.

To: enumerated

You don’t need a bill - it’s in the Constitution.
And I believe the Constitution says it's the state legislatures.

"We need to get back to 1958-style voting."
